Award.AwardTitle: Supporting College and Career Education through Student Scholarships in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (SuCCESS in STEM)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The "Supporting College and Career Education through Student Scholarships in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (SuCCESS in STEM)" project at Pellissippi State Community College will support 24 nontraditional students with scholarships up to $8,500 per year over 2.5 years. The project will increase the participation of financially-disadvantaged, nontraditional students in post-secondary opportunities in high-demand STEM areas in East Tennessee. Support services will be designed and implemented to ensure that scholars successfully complete an associate degree and are prepared to either enter the workforce or transfer to a four-year institution upon graduation. Real-world experiences through targeted strategies such as internships, mentoring, and shadowing with assistance of established partnerships with local industry will support the successful transition of scholars into either employment or continuing post-secondary education.

Quantitative and qualitative data will be collected for both a formative and summative evaluation that will measure the overall impact of the program. A comparison of student success and graduation rates will be performed between scholars who are required to use these support services versus students who voluntarily use these services. Research will focus on the efficacy of support services and interventions that support the retention of scholars, specifically focusing on improving the success of under-resourced, nontraditional students in STEM disciplines. The results of this study will be disseminated to the higher education academic community and will provide guidance on intervention strategies such as scholarship programs, cohorts, supplemental instruction, and experiential learning for recruiting and retaining under-resourced students in STEM disciplines in a two-year college environment.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Pellissippi State Community College began this project in the Fall of 2016. At that time it proposed to implement the PSCC SuCCESS in STEM scholarship program to at least 34 scholar-students. The students would be awarded scholarships up to $6,000 per year over 2.5 years enabling them to pursue degrees related to the following STEM fields: Agricultural Science, Animal Science, Engineering Technology, and Mathematics.

The project had three specific objectives to be assessed and evaluated:   to increase participation of financially-disadvantaged students, particularly underrepresented groups, in postsecondary opportunities in STEM areas of demand in East Tennessee and nationwide; to provide support services that promote the success and retention of selected scholars to complete an associate degree and/or transfer to a four-year institution to continue pursuit of a baccalaureate degree in a STEM area; and to provide real-world experiences through targeted strategies such as internships, mentoring, and shadowing with assistance of established partnerships that support the successful transition of selected scholars into either employment or continuing postsecondary education.

The recruitment during the initial phase had three (3) students enrolled into the program. As the program was entering its second year, Pellissippi State announced the creation and implementation of Pellissippi Reconnect. This scholarship program targeted the same demographic that the SuCCESS in STEM scholarship program did. At that time the State of Tennessee announced the establishment of the Tennessee Reconnect Grant. This grant program also targeted the student demographic initially targeted by the SuCCESS in STEM project.

The SuCCESS in STEM scholarship program required students to maintain a minimum 3.0 GPA  and to take a full 12-hour course load. The Pellissippi Reconnect and Tennessee Reconnect programs only required students to maintain a 2.0 GPA  and a 6-hour course load. The differences between the SuCCESS in STEM scholarship program and the Reconnect Programs were  a major hurdle. In the fall of 2018,  the criteria for the SuCCESS in STEM scholarship program was expanded to include more STEM majors. This expansion allowed for a broader pool of student applicants. The recruitment process was also enhanced to better identify potential students.

By the end of the SuCCESS in STEM scholarship program, 17 students were awarded scholarships; nine of these students  completed their degree programs and graduated from Pellissippi State. The other eight  students lost their scholarship due to low GPA, dropping below the 12-hour load, or changing majors. The Pellissippi State SuCCESS in STEM project team members  believe that the inability to recruit or maintain students in the program was due to both the high GPA and 12- hour course load requirements. Students in the STEM field in this demographic typically work outside of school, and these two requirements put an excessive burden on them. The other scholarship programs introduced during the course of this program gave students a less stringent route to complete their degree programs. It is worth noting that the latest S-STEM solicitation has changed the requirement to allow scholars to be part-time, which is in alignment with Pellissippi State’s SuCCESS in STEM  findings.
